children.name: dependable
children.definition: able to be trusted to do what you need or expect :đáng tin cậy
examples: a dependable car
our most dependable ally
a dependable source of income

children.name: reliable
children.definition: /rɪˈlaɪəbəl/  a reliable machine, system etc always works well; reliable information, books etc do not contain mistakes and are likely to be correct:

children.name: đáng tin cậy
examples: ▪ Do you have a reliable map of the area?
▪ My car’s quite old, but it’s still pretty reliable.
▪ In those days there was no reliable system of transportation between Alaska and the rest of the US.

children.name: can depend on
children.definition: can rely/depend onsthB2  if you  sth or can rely on it, you can be sure that it will always work well : có thể tin cậy, tin tưởng
examples: ▪ You can depend on the postal service here. It’s very good.
▪ If we can rely on the weather report, it’s going to be hot tomorrow.
▪ Of course people will use their cars if they cannot depend on buses and trains to get them to work.

children.name: the feeling that you can trust sb/sth
trust
children.definition: a strong belief in the honesty, goodness etc of sb/sth :sự tin cậy, tin tưởng
examples: At first there was alack of trustbetween them.
a relationship based on trust and understanding
He's ina position oftrust (= a position with responsibilities, especially to the public) .
mutual trustwhen two people or groups trust each other :
To be good leaders, managers must create a climate of mutual trust and respect.
an agreement made on the basis ofmutual trust
trust in
Despite her many misfortunes, her trust in God was never shaken.
put/place your trust in sb/sth
You shouldn’t put your trust in a man like that.
People put their trust in their elected officials and expect them to do the best job they can.
betray sb’s trustdo sth that shows they should not have trusted you
She has betrayed the trust which we placed in her.
Youbetrayedyour father’strust.

children.name: confidence
children.definition: the feeling that you can trust sb/sth to be good, work well, or produce good results : niềm tin , lòng tin
examples: The new president has the confidence and backing of all of the leaders of the surrounding states.

children.name: have confidence in somebody/something
examples: The people no longer have any confidence in their government.

children.name: lose confidence in somebody/something
examples: Employees are losing confidence in the company.

children.name: gain/win sb’s confidence
examples: As team captain, he soon won the confidence of the players.

children.name: inspire confidence
children.definition: make people have confidence
examples: Our education system should inspire public confidence.

children.name: restore confidence
children.definition: make people have confidence again
examples: Interest rate reductions would restore business confidence.

children.name: boost confidence
children.definition: make people have more confidence
examples: The government is keen to boost consumer confidence and spending.

children.name: shake sb’s confidence
children.definition: make them have less confidence
examples: The stock market fall has shaken the confidence of investors.

children.name: undermine/damage/weaken sb’s confidence
children.definition: make someone have less confidence
examples: The situation in the US was undermining foreign confidence in the dollar.

children.name: destroy/shatter confidence in somebody/something
examples: A further crisis has destroyed public confidence in the bank.

children.name: have every/complete/absolute confidence in somebody/something
examples: A manager must be able to have complete confidence in his staff.

children.name: a crisis of confidence
children.definition: a situation in which people no longer trust a government, system etc
examples: the crisis of confidence over food safety

children.name: public confidence
examples: The changes should improve public confidence in the system.

children.name: consumer confidence
children.definition: that ordinary people have when the economic situation is good
examples: Consumer confidence has fallen to its lowest for two years.

children.name: business confidence
children.definition: that businesses have when the economic situation is good
examples: The region has gained 46,000 jobs and business confidence is high.

children.name: investor confidence
children.definition: that investors have when the economic situation is good
examples: A fall in the value of shares damages investor confidence.

children.name: confidence in
examples: Public confidence in the government is at an all-time low.
She had complete confidence in the doctors.
Opinion polls show that voters have lost confidence in the administration.

children.name: a lack of confidencethe public’s lack of confidence in the National Health Service
faith
children.definition: a strong belief that sb/sth can always be depended onto do or say what is right or good:niềm tin
examples: faith in
My mother’s total faith in God always amazed

children.name: have faith
examples: The public no longer has faith in the government’s policies.

children.name: have every faith in sb/sth
children.definition: trust them completely
examples: We have every faith in your ability to solve the problem.

children.name: put/place your faith in somebody/something
examples: The Conservative party put its faith in the free market.

children.name: show faith in somebody/something
examples: The club have shown faith in the young goalkeeper by offering him a permanent contract.

children.name: lose faith
examples: Local people have lost faith in the police.

children.name: destroy sb’s faith in somebody/something
examples: Terry’s lies had destroyed Liz’s faith in men.

children.name: restore sb’s faith in somebody/something
children.definition: make sb’s faith return
examples: His kindness had restored her faith in human nature.

children.name: great faith
examples: He had great faith in his team.

children.name: enormous faith
examples: Ford placed enormous faith in the new model.

children.name: complete faith
examples: The owners have complete faith in Sam as manager.

children.name: blind faith
children.definition: trusting someone without thinking
examples: niềm tin mù quángHe believes that our blind faith in technology is misplaced.

children.name: the feeling that you cannot trust sb/sth
distrust
children.definition: /mistrust the feeling that you cannot trust sb, especially because you think they may treat you unfairly or dishonestly :sự nghi ngờ, ngờ vực, hoài nghi
examples: The talks took place in an atmosphere of hostility and distrust.
The city’s school system has been hurt by low morale and public mistrust.

children.name: distrust/mistrust of
examples: Dylan’s natural mistrust of reporters makes him a difficult man to interview.
He had a deep mistrust of the legal profession.

children.name: (of sb) not usually trust other people
suspicious
children.definition: hay ngờ vực , đa nghi
examples: The officials we met in the capital looked suspicious and tense, as if they were expecting us to declare war on them.

children.name: suspicious of
examples: The local people were suspicious of me because of my somewhat unusual lifestyle.
She was always suspicious of strangers.
He wasdeeply suspiciousof the legal system.

children.name: distrustful
children.definition: / mistrustfulhay ngờ vực , đa nghi
examples: He was unsociable and distrustful, but also a fanatical worker.

children.name: distrustful/mistrustful of
examples: For nearly a whole century, Eastern and Western Europe remained deeply distrustful of each other.
Many people are still very mistrustful of computers.
Some people are very mistrustful of computerised banking.

children.name: can depend on
children.definition: /rely on sbB2 if you can depend on sb or can rely on them, you can be sure that they will do what you want or need them to do:có thể tin cậy vào
examples: It’s going to be a stressful time - you’ll need to have someone with you who you can depend on.

children.name: can depend/rely on sb to do sth
examples: We knew we could rely on Tom to bring some good music.

children.name: dependable
children.definition: able to be trusted to do what you need or expect :đáng tin cậy
examples: I need someone dependable to look after the children while I'm at work.

children.name: reliable
children.definition: sbwho is reliable can be trusted to do what they say they will do andnotmakeanymistakes:đáng tin cậy
examples: It’s strange Ben isn’t here. He’s usually so reliable.
In many offices the most reliable people with the longest service are the secretaries.

children.name: trustworthy
children.definition: especiallywrittenifsbis trustworthy, you can trust them because they are honest:đáng tin cậy
examples: We got the information from a trustworthy source.
Most of our employees are pretty trustworthy, I think.
Many people do not see politicians as trustworthy.

children.name: responsible
children.definition: someone who is responsible can be trusted to behave in asensibleway, so you do not need to worry that they will do somethingcarelessorstupid:đáng tin cậy, có trách nhiệm
examples: ▪ We never worried about letting Sam babysit our kids - he’d always seemed very responsible and intelligent.
▪ He treated me as if I wasn’t responsible enough to be given the tools to do my job.

children.name: responsible behaviour/decisions etc
examples: ▪ Two new programs are being developed to help promote responsible sexual behavior.

children.name: trust
children.definition: to believe that sb is honest or will not do anything bad or wrongOPP distrust,mistrust:
examples: I just don’t trust him.
can trust sbfeel sure that they are honest :
The hardest thing is finding a car dealer you can trust!
(can) trust sb to do sth
‘He’s only fourteen.’ ‘I know, but I think we can trust him to look after the baby for an hour.’
Can they be trusted to look after the house?
I didn’t trust myself not to say something rude, so I just kept quiet.
trust sb completely/implicitly
He was a good driver and I trusted him implicitly.
not trust sb an inch/not trust sb as far as you can throw them(= not trust sb at all )

children.name: trust
children.definition: 1 facts/judgementto be sure that something is correct or rightSYN believe in,rely on:
examples: Can we trust these statistics?
Itrusthisjudgementcompletely.
Trustyourinstincts(= do what you feel is the right thing )!
2 thingsto be sure that something will work properlySYN rely on:
Not trusting her voice, she shook her head.

children.name: trust sth to do sth
examples: You can’t trust the trains to run on time.
He sat down suddenly, as if he didn’t trust his legs to support him.

children.name: not trust
children.definition: không tin tưởng
examples: ▪ I don’t know what to do. I mean if I can’t trust my best friend, who can I trust?
▪ Don’t trust him. He’s lying.

children.name: not trust sb with sth
examples: ▪ I wouldn’t trust him with my money.
▪ It can be difficult to trust anyone with some of your innermost secrets.

children.name: not trust sb an inchBritish not trust sb at all
examples: ▪ I thing you’re mad giving him such an important job. I wouldn’t trust him an inch.
not trust sb as far as you can throw themnot trust sb at all :
▪ As for his ‘advisors’, he said he wouldn’t trust them as far as he could throw them.

children.name: distrust
children.definition: to not trust sb/sth:
examples: She had every reason to distrust him.
In spite of its election success, the government is stilldeeplydistrusted on key issues.

children.name: mistrust
children.definition: to not trust sb, especially because you think they may treat you unfairly or dishonestly:
examples: As a very small child she had learned to mistrust adults.

children.name: sb can’t be trusted
children.definition: spoken say this about sb you do not trust:
examples: ▪ Many people feel that lawyers can’t be trusted, that they are just out for the money and nothing else.

children.name: sb can’t be trusted to do sth
examples: ▪ Sharon can’t be trusted to look after her own money, let alone deal with other people’s.

children.name: sb can’t be trusted with
examples: ▪ Don’t say anything to Ed - he can’t be trusted with confidential information.

children.name: can't trust
children.definition: can’t trust/ can’t rely onB2  to be unable to trust sb to do what they say they will do, or to be unable to trust a machine, system etc to work well:không thể tin tưởng, trông cậy
examples: You can’t rely on the buses. I’ve stood here for twenty minutes waiting for one to come.
British weather can never be relied on - it's always changing.

children.name: can’t rely on to do sth
examples: We need clearer regulations, but you can’t trust the government to simplify anything.

children.name: sb looks suspicious
children.definition: sb looks/seems suspicioususe this sb someone whose appearance or behaviour makes you think that they may intend to do somethingdishonestorharmful: trông đáng ngờ
examples: ▪ The cop said we looked suspicious and that he was arresting us - just for standing on a corner!
▪ The whole operation seemed very suspicious to me, so I thought I’d take a closer look.

children.name: unreliable
children.definition: if sb is unreliable, you cannot be sure that they will do what they say they will do; if amachine, car etc is unreliable, itoftenstopsworkingand you cannot be sure it will work well:không đáng tin cậy
examples: We could ask our neighbours to feed the cat, but they’re a little unreliable.
Telephone service in most of the country is unreliable.
The car’s becoming very unreliable.

children.name: count on sb
children.definition: count onsbphrasal verb
examples: _[ + to infinitive ]I can count on my parentstohelp me.

children.name: to be confident that you can depend on someone
examples: _You can always count on Michael in a crisis.
